video_caption: The video begins with a black screen displaying white text that credits the video's development by Labs for Life, a partnership project of the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare (MoHFW) and the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). It then transitions to another black screen with white text explaining the video's educational purpose, its Creative Commons Attribution license, and the entities involved in its production. Following this, a slide titled "Haemoglobin by Cyanomethemoglobin Method" appears, listing the learning objectives of the video, which include understanding the principle, procedure, quality control, and result interpretation of haemoglobin estimation by Drabkin's method. The video then shifts to a blue background with yellow text stating "Hb Estimation by Cyanmethemoglobin Method," followed by a slide emphasizing that this method is internationally recommended for determining hemoglobin. The video maintains a professional and educational tone throughout, focusing on the content and objectives of the haemoglobin estimation method.

The video begins with a title slide displaying the text "Hb Estimation by Cyanmethemoglobin Method" in yellow font against a dark blue background, with the word "Principle" in light blue font below it. The slide then transitions to include additional text in green font, explaining the principle of the method: "Blood + Reagent solution (Potassium cyanide and potassium ferricyanide)." This text is followed by a further explanation in white font, stating "Converts Hb to methemoglobin," and then "Cyanmethemoglobin," indicating the chemical process involved in the estimation of hemoglobin (Hb) using the cyanmethemoglobin method. The background remains consistently dark blue throughout the video, providing a clear contrast for the text. The video serves as an educational presentation, detailing the chemical process behind the cyanmethemoglobin method for estimating hemoglobin levels.

The video begins with a slide titled "Hb Estimation by Cyanmethemoglobin Method," explaining the principle behind the method. It details how blood mixed with a reagent solution containing potassium cyanide and potassium ferricyanide converts hemoglobin (Hb) to methemoglobin, forming cyanmethemoglobin. The absorbance of this compound is measured using a spectrophotometer at a wavelength of 540nm or a colorimeter with a yellow-green filter. The slide then transitions to a section labeled "Equipment," showcasing a micro pipette and a colorimeter or spectrophotometer. The colorimeter or spectrophotometer is highlighted with a note that the principle applied is the same, but the wavelengths available for estimation differ. The background throughout the video is a consistent dark blue, and the text is presented in a clear, easy-to-read format. The video provides a concise overview of the method and the necessary equipment for Hb estimation by cyanmethemoglobin method.

The video begins with a title slide introducing the "Hb Estimation by Cyanmethemoglobin Method," focusing on the reagents required for the procedure. The slide features a white bottle labeled "Drabkin's solution" against a blue background, with text detailing the necessary reagents. The pH of the solution is specified as 7.0-7.4, and additional notes mention the solution's instability when exposed to light and its storage requirements in brown borosilicate bottles at room temperature. The slide transitions to show a clear, pale yellow solution in a test tube, emphasizing the solution's appearance. The video then shifts to a close-up of an Elico CL 223 Colorimeter, displaying a reading of 0.0054, with a gloved hand adjusting the device. The setting appears to be a laboratory, with a focus on the equipment and the procedural steps involved in the Hb estimation process.

The video presents a slide titled "Hb Estimation by Cyanmethemoglobin Method," focusing on the reagents required for the procedure. The slide features an image of a white bottle labeled "Drabkin's solution" on the left side. The background is a dark blue gradient, and the text is displayed in various colors, including yellow, blue, and green. The slide provides instructions on how to handle the Drabkin's solution, such as storing it in a refrigerator if the room temperature exceeds 30Â°C and bringing it to room temperature before use. It also advises discarding the solution if it becomes turbid or if the pH is outside the specified range. Additionally, the slide warns against pipetting the solution by mouth. The slide remains static throughout the video, with no visible changes or movements.

The video presents a slide titled "Hb Estimation by Cyanmethemoglobin Method," focusing on the reagents required for the procedure. The slide features a dark blue background with a white trapezoidal inset displaying a gloved hand holding a small brown bottle labeled "Hb Standard solution." The text on the slide, in yellow and white, outlines the necessary reagents, starting with their commercial availability at a specific concentration. It then explains that the solution is stored in a brown bottle due to its photosensitivity, with exposure to light causing deterioration in the standard's strength. The concentration of the standard used in this method is specified as 14.8 gm%, with a note that the derivation of this number will be discussed later. The slide maintains a consistent layout and color scheme throughout, emphasizing the importance of proper storage and handling of the Hb Standard solution for accurate hemoglobin estimation.

The video begins with a title slide introducing the "Hb Estimation by Cyanmethemoglobin Method," highlighting the reagents required for the procedure. The slide features a dark blue background with yellow and light blue text, listing "Sample" as one of the necessary components. The scene transitions to a laboratory setting where a gloved hand is seen holding a test tube rack containing three test tubes, two of which are filled with yellow liquid. The hand is then shown adding a red liquid, presumably blood, into one of the test tubes using a pipette. The video continues to focus on the laboratory environment, showcasing the meticulous process of adding the red liquid to the test tubes, emphasizing the precision and care taken in the procedure. The background remains consistent, featuring a clean, white laboratory surface and a digital timer displaying "0:00," indicating the start of the timing for the experiment. The video begins with a close-up shot of an Elico CL 223 Colorimeter, a device used for measuring the concentration of substances in a solution. The digital display shows a reading of 2.0054, and the device is placed on a white surface with a black power cord extending from the back. A person wearing a white glove is seen placing a small test tube with an orange liquid into the colorimeter's sample holder. The display changes to show a reading of 0.1454, indicating the device is analyzing the sample. The person adjusts the sample tube, and the display changes again to show a reading of 0.3254. The scene then transitions to a blue background with text that reads "Hb Estimation by Cyanmethemoglobin Method" and "Calculate the hemoglobin concentration," suggesting that the video is demonstrating the use of the colorimeter for hemoglobin estimation. The video concludes with this informative text on the screen.

The video features a slide with a dark blue background and a formula for calculating hemoglobin concentration using the Cyanmethemoglobin method. The title at the top reads "Hb Estimation by Cyanmethemoglobin Method" in yellow text, followed by the subtitle "Calculate the hemoglobin concentration" in light blue text. Below the title, the formula is presented in white text, with the equation "Conc. of Hb in sample = (Absorbance of sample / Absorbance of standard) x Conc. of standard." The slide remains static throughout the video, with no changes in the background, text, or any other elements. The focus is solely on the educational content related to hemoglobin estimation.

The video begins with a title slide introducing the "Hb Estimation by Cyanmethemoglobin Method" and instructs viewers to calculate the hemoglobin concentration. It mentions that the concentration of the standard is available on the kit insert. The next slide elaborates on the procedure, advising to measure the absorbance of the standard against a blank of Drabkin's solution. The video then transitions to a slide titled "Preparation of Standard curve for Hemoglobin estimation by Cyanmethemoglobin method." Following this, a person wearing white gloves and a red wristband is shown pointing at a large white bottle labeled "Hb Standard" and a smaller bottle labeled "Hb Standard 100 mg/dL." The video then returns to a slide explaining that the concentration of the standard used in the demonstration is 14.8 gm%, with a note that the derivation of this number will be discussed later. The final slide mentions the availability of a WHO International reference HiCN standard commercially as 10ml sealed ampoules and its stability for years. Throughout the video, the background remains a dark blue gradient, and the text is presented in a clear, legible font. The video appears to be an instructional guide on hemoglobin estimation using the cyanmethemoglobin method, with a focus on the preparation of a standard curve and the use of specific reagents.

The video begins with a title slide introducing the "Hb Estimation by Cyanmethemoglobin Method" and the preparation of a standard curve for hemoglobin estimation using this method. The slide features a dark blue background with yellow and light blue text. A yellow arrow points to the instruction "Make serial dilutions of the standard solution with Drabkin's solution." The scene transitions to a laboratory setting where a person wearing white gloves is seen handling test tubes in a rack. The person is using a pipette to transfer a yellow liquid into the test tubes. A table is displayed on the right side of the screen, detailing the serial dilutions of the standard solution with Drabkin's solution, including the test tube number, standard volume, Drabkin's solution volume, and dilution factor. The table is updated sequentially as the person continues to fill the test tubes with the yellow liquid, with each row of the table corresponding to the test tube number and its respective dilution details. The video maintains a consistent laboratory environment throughout, with a focus on the precise preparation of the standard curve for hemoglobin estimation.

The video begins with a slide titled "Hb Estimation by Cyanmethemoglobin Method" and "Preparation of Standard curve for Hemoglobin estimation by Cyanmethemoglobin method." It features a table with columns labeled "TT No.," "Std Vol (mL)," "Drabkin's solution Vol (mL)," "Dilution factor," and "Value of Hb." The slide explains the strength of the standard as 14.8 gm/dL and provides a formula for calculating the value of Hb. The table lists different dilution factors and corresponding values of Hb. The scene transitions to a laboratory setting where a person wearing gloves is seen using a colorimeter, a device used for measuring the concentration of a substance in a solution. The colorimeter displays a reading of "CAL 54," indicating it is in calibration mode. The person is holding a test tube and appears to be preparing a sample for analysis. The video then returns to the slide, now showing the addition of an "OD" (Optical Density) column to the table, with corresponding values filled in for each dilution factor. The table is updated with the OD values, which are used to create a standard curve for hemoglobin estimation. The video concludes with a close-up of the table, highlighting the OD values and the final value of Hb for each dilution factor.

The video begins with a title slide introducing the topic of "Hb Estimation by Cyanmethemoglobin Method" and the preparation of a standard curve for hemoglobin estimation using this method. The background is a gradient of dark blue, and the text is in yellow and light blue. The first frame shows a blank graph paper, followed by a graph with a plotted line indicating the relationship between hemoglobin concentration and absorbance value. The graph is labeled with "Concentration of Hb (gm/L)" on the x-axis and "Absorbance value" on the y-axis. The next frame shows a computer screen with an Excel spreadsheet and a graph, indicating that plotting on an Excel sheet will be discussed in the next video. The video then transitions to a hand holding a paper with a handwritten standard curve for hemoglobin estimation, labeled with "STANDARD CURVE FOR Hb" and "Dept. of Hematology, MGM hospital, Warangal." The hand points to specific points on the graph, emphasizing the importance of these values in the estimation process. The video concludes with a slide explaining that after the optical density (OD) of the sample is taken, the corresponding hemoglobin value can be directly read by plotting on the graph. The overall setting is educational, with a focus on the scientific method of hemoglobin estimation.

The video begins with a title slide introducing the "Hb Estimation by Cyanmethemoglobin Method," followed by a slide explaining the preparation of a standard curve for hemoglobin estimation using this method, emphasizing the need for a new calibration curve whenever necessary. The next slide lists the advantages of this method, highlighting the elimination of visual error and the availability of a reliable reference standard from WHO. Subsequently, the video transitions to a slide detailing the disadvantages, noting that the conversion rate of blood containing carboxyhemoglobin is slowed and that high leucocyte counts can cause turbidity during blood dilution. The final slide presents a reference range for hemoglobin levels in grams per deciliter (gm/dL) across various age groups, from birth to 12 years, and for males and females. The background throughout the video is a consistent dark blue gradient, and the text is presented in a clear, legible font with a professional and educational tone.
